intro: Antirrhinum triphyllum var. minor, commonly known as the lesser trifoliate toadflax, is a flowering plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It is a perennial herb that typically grows to a height of 20–60 cm, featuring opposite, trifoliate leaves that are often hairy. The plant produces showy, two-lipped flowers that are typically pink or purple in color, arranged in racemes. It thrives in well-drained soils and prefers full sun to partial shade. Due to its ornamental value and adaptability, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens.
